content:
The decision once again puts political concerns above the need for clean sport

<span class="word-wrap-span">RUSSIANspan> sport is coming in from the cold. On September 20th the <span class="word-wrap-span">executivespan> committee of the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) voted to <span class="word-wrap-span">provisionallyspan> <span class="word-wrap-span"><span class="word-wrap-span">reinstatespan>span> the <span class="word-wrap-span">RUSSIANspan> Anti-Doping Agency (RUSADA), an important step towards reintegrating the country and its athletes into international sport. RUSADA, which <span class="word-wrap-span">facilitatespan>d a state-sponsored scheme to replace positive urine <span class="word-wrap-span">samplespan>s with clean ones during the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, has been banned since November 2015. It has not met two of WADA’s original <span class="word-wrap-span">criteriaspan> for <span class="word-wrap-span"><span class="word-wrap-span">reinstatespan>span>ment: an <span class="word-wrap-span">acknowledgespan>ment of the <span class="word-wrap-span">severityspan> of its violations and the release of data and <span class="word-wrap-span">samplespan>s from the Moscow Laboratory, the centre of its <span class="word-wrap-span">illicitspan> operations. Last week’s decision softens those <span class="word-wrap-span">criteriaspan>. RUSADA now has until December 31st to <span class="word-wrap-span">revealspan> its database, and until June 30th next year to provide <span class="word-wrap-span">samplespan>s for <span class="word-wrap-span">retestspan>ing.

Athletes’ committees, sporting <span class="word-wrap-span">federationspan>s, and other national anti-doping agencies have immediately seen the vote for what it is: a <span class="word-wrap-span">cravenspan> move that allows Russia to save face and edge its way back into the good <span class="word-wrap-span">gracespan>s of international sport, while showing the rest of the world that powerful countries need not play by the rules. WADA’s forgiveness suits the International Olympic Committee (IOC), which provides half of WADA’s funding and committee members, and which wants to bring Russia back into the fold. Doing so means that the country can bid for hosting rights at major events. Indeed, immediately after RUSADA’s <span class="word-wrap-span"><span class="word-wrap-span">reinstatespan>span>ment, <span class="word-wrap-span">Kazanspan> was named on the <span class="word-wrap-span">shortlistspan> of hosts for the 2023 European Games, an Olympic-style event for the <span class="word-wrap-span">continentspan>.

WADA’s <span class="word-wrap-span">feeblespan> decision has undermined its <span class="word-wrap-span">explicitspan> purpose, which is to keep sport clean. In its <span class="word-wrap-span">compromisespan> with stubborn Russian officials, the agency softened its demand that RUSADA should <span class="word-wrap-span">acknowledgespan> the findings of the McLaren report, an investigation in 2016 that <span class="word-wrap-span">demonstratespan>d the Russian government’s <span class="word-wrap-span">conspiracyspan> to hide evidence of <span class="word-wrap-span">pervasivespan> doping. Instead, WADA accepted a <span class="word-wrap-span">considerablyspan> weaker statement from the sports minister, Pavel Kolobkov, who “fully accepted the decision of the International Olympic Committee <span class="word-wrap-span">executivespan> board that was made based on the findings of the Schmid Report.” The Schmid report confirmed many of the McLaren report’s findings—but stopped short of <span class="word-wrap-span">assignspan>ing blame to “the highest State authority”.

Both reports made clear that, wherever the <span class="word-wrap-span">buckspan> stops, the level of doping and the effort to cover it up <span class="word-wrap-span">representspan> the worst offences since East Germany’s state-sponsored scheme in the 1980s. Beginning in 2010, a series of whistleblowers <span class="word-wrap-span">revealspan>ed an extensive doping programme to WADA, which <span class="word-wrap-span">culminatespan>d in a <span class="word-wrap-span">coordinatespan>d effort by several organs of state power (including the <span class="word-wrap-span">Federaspan>l Security Service (FSB), the successor to the <span class="word-wrap-span">KGBspan>) to maximise Russia’s <span class="word-wrap-span">medalspan> count at the Sochi games. After a series of WADA investigations, 13 <span class="word-wrap-span">medalspan>lists from Sochi were stripped of their awards, 111 athletes were prevented from competing at the 2016 Summer Olympics in <span class="word-wrap-span">Riospan> de Janeiro, and Russian competitors were required to participate under a <span class="word-wrap-span">neutralspan> flag at this year’s Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang.

RUSADA’s <span class="word-wrap-span"><span class="word-wrap-span">reinstatespan>span>ment does not fully return Russian sport to its pre-ban footing. But it is the biggest step in that direction since the IOC <span class="word-wrap-span">overlookspan>ed two positive drugs tests during the Pyeongchang games and restored the status of the Russian Olympic Committee three days after the closing ceremony. The agency will once again be able to <span class="word-wrap-span">certifyspan> its own athletes and issue therapeutic-use <span class="word-wrap-span">exemptionspan>s for <span class="word-wrap-span">prohibitspan>ed substances. 

The remaining obstacles for Russian competitors are the few governing bodies that have taken anti-doping <span class="word-wrap-span">disciplinespan> into their own hands. The most <span class="word-wrap-span">prominentspan> is the International Association of <span class="word-wrap-span">Athleticspan>s <span class="word-wrap-span">Federationspan>s (IAAF), which governs track-and-field events and is unhappy with WADA’s decision. The IAAF independently banned Russian athletes from its competitions in 2015. Though RUSADA’s return to WADA’s good <span class="word-wrap-span">gracespan>s is one of the IAAF’s <span class="word-wrap-span">criteriaspan> for <span class="word-wrap-span"><span class="word-wrap-span">reinstatespan>span>ment, the <span class="word-wrap-span">Athleticspan>s association appears determined to stick to its remaining demands, which include <span class="word-wrap-span">acknowledgespan>ment of the McLaren report. The International Paralympic Committee has established another path, which involves <span class="word-wrap-span">repaymentspan> of testing-related costs and, once again, a statement regarding the McLaren findings. Russia’s weightlifting team is also serving a one-year suspension for failed drugs tests. 

In the eyes of many athletes, these sporting bodies, despite their need to balance anti-doping efforts with other priorities, are <span class="word-wrap-span">fulfillspan>ing a role that WADA has abandoned. WADA’s committee for athletes gives its members a platform, but little power. After WADA’s <span class="word-wrap-span">compliancespan> committee recommended reinstating RUSADA ahead of Thursday’s vote, Canadian <span class="word-wrap-span">skierspan> Beckie Scott, both a member of the <span class="word-wrap-span">compliancespan> body and the head of the athlete committee, resigned from the former.

Athletes are right to be concerned. A global anti-doping body without WADA’s conflicted interests is crucial to maintain clean sport, and alternatives are thin on the ground. In June the IOC launched its own International Testing Agency, but it is hard to imagine an IOC-funded <span class="word-wrap-span">entityspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">representspan>ing an improvement. Institutions like the IAAF may police their own events, but dozens of smaller <span class="word-wrap-span">Federationspan>s would struggle to do the same. In 2015 the Danish Institute of Sports Studies <span class="word-wrap-span">gradspan>ed all of the Olympic-<span class="word-wrap-span">affiliatespan>d <span class="word-wrap-span">Federationspan>s. It found that only one—the International <span class="word-wrap-span">Federationspan> for <span class="word-wrap-span">Equestrianspan> Sports—met its “basic <span class="word-wrap-span">criteriaspan> of good <span class="word-wrap-span">governancespan>.” To take just one example, the IOC suspended payments to the International <span class="word-wrap-span">Biathlonspan> Union this year after an Austrian police investigation <span class="word-wrap-span">allegespan>d that the organisation had taken <span class="word-wrap-span">bribespan>s to cover up Russian doping cases over a span of six years. (Two of its former employees deny those charges.)

It is still possible for WADA to show that it can serve as a global anti-doping <span class="word-wrap-span">patrolspan>. But by weakening its own <span class="word-wrap-span">sanctionspan>s and alienating athletes, it has made that task harder. Having <span class="word-wrap-span">cavespan>d on Russia’s <span class="word-wrap-span">acknowledgespan>ment of the McLaren report, the agency must hold firm on its demand for <span class="word-wrap-span">deliveryspan> of physical and digital evidence that will shed more light on past offences. If the recent <span class="word-wrap-span">compromisespan> loosens Russia’s <span class="word-wrap-span">gripspan> on incriminating evidence, then WADA can sort through the archives and <span class="word-wrap-span">gradspan>ually close the door on one of sport’s most <span class="word-wrap-span">sordidspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">scandalspan>s. But if the vote is an <span class="word-wrap-span">indicationspan> that anti-doping efforts are yet again being suppressed by the needs of governing bodies like the IOC, then cheating officials will continue to see WADA as little more than a <span class="word-wrap-span">pestspan>. The world’s athletes and fans deserve better.
